abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Knowledge of the frequency of rare <jats:italic>SERPINA1</jats:italic> mutations could help in the management of alpha1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD). The present study aims to assess the frequencies of rare and null alleles and their respiratory and hepatic pathogenicity.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>This is a secondary analysis of a study that evaluated the viability of the Progenika diagnostic genotyping system in six different countries by analyzing 30,827 samples from cases of suspected AATD. Allele-specific genotyping was carried out with the Progenika A1AT Genotyping Test which analyses 14 mutations in buccal swabs or dried blood spots samples. <jats:italic>SERPINA1</jats:italic> gene sequencing was performed for serum AAT-genotype discrepancies or by request of the clinician. Only cases with rare mutations were included in this analysis.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>There were 818 cases (2.6%) carrying a rare allele, excluding newly identified mutations. All were heterozygous except for 20 that were homozygous. The most frequent alleles were the M-like alleles, PI*M<jats:sub>malton</jats:sub> and PI*M<jats:sub>heerlen</jats:sub>. Of the 14 mutations included in the Progenika panel, there were no cases detected of PI*S<jats:sub>iiyama</jats:sub>, PI*Q0<jats:sub>granite falls</jats:sub> and PI*Q0<jats:sub>west</jats:sub>. Other alleles not included in the 14-mutation panel and identified by gene sequencing included PI*M<jats:sub>würzburg</jats:sub>, PI*Z<jats:sub>bristol</jats:sub>, and PI*Z<jats:sub>wrexham</jats:sub>, and the null alleles PI*Q0<jats:sub>porto</jats:sub>, PI*Q0<jats:sub>madrid</jats:sub>, PI*Q0<jats:sub>brescia</jats:sub>, and PI*Q0<jats:sub>kayseri</jats:sub>.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The Progenika diagnostic network has allowed the identification of several rare alleles, some unexpected and not included in the initial diagnostic panel. This establishes a new perspective on the distribution of these alleles in different countries. These findings may help prioritize allele selection for routine testing and highlights the need for further research into their pathogenetic role.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: This study reports the results of a diagnostic procedure that is approved for use in all the participating countries and, therefore, constitutes standard clinical practice. Consequently, since it is not an experimental procedure, approval by an ethics committee was not considered necessary. All patients included signed a written informed consent form.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: JLLC has received honoraria during the last 3 years for lecturing, scientific advice, participation in clinical studies or writing for publications for (alphabetical order): AstraZeneca, Bial, Boehringer, Chiesi, CSL Behring, Faes, Ferrer, Gebro, Grifols, GSK, Megalabs, Menarini, Novartis. MM has received speaker fees from AstraZeneca, Boehringer Ingelheim, Chiesi, Cipla, Menarini, Kamada, Takeda, Zambon, CSL Behring, Specialty Therapeutics, Janssen, Grifols and Novartis, consulting fees from AstraZeneca, Atriva Therapeutics, Boehringer Ingelheim, Chiesi, GlaxoSmithKline, CSL Behring, Inhibrx, Ferrer, Menarini, Mereo Biopharma, Spin Therapeutics, ONO Pharma, Palobiofarma SL, Takeda, Novartis, Sanofi and Grifols and research grants from Grifols. LO works as geneticist at Progenika Biopharma, a Grifols Company. ED works in Scientific and Medical Affairs at Grifols.
